channel.title: What the fuck
channel.description:
so i ran my exception entry transformer on this method, and this was the result: [code]static final void c(int); Code: 0: getstatic #337; //Field client.ib:Z 3: istore 19 5: getstatic #339; //Field N:I 8: iconst_1 9: iadd 10: putstatic #339; //Field ij.z:I 496: imul 497: iadd 498: putfield #354; //Field fj.mc:I 501: aload_2 502: iload 11 504: putfield #359; //Field fj.yc:I 507: aload_2 508: aload_1 509: getfield #375; //Field ij.x:I 512: getstatic #382; //Field ij.u:I 564: istore 17 566: iload 17 568: iload 16 570: if_icmpge 585 573: iload 16 575: istore 18 577: iload 17 579: istore 16 581: iload 18 583: istore 17 585: aload_2 586: aload_1 587: getfield #376; //Field ij.z:I 590: iload 15 592: ineg 593: isub 594: putfield #356; //Field fj.oc:I 597: aload_2 598: iload 14 600: aload_1 601: getfield #376; //Field ij.z:I 604: iadd 605: putfield #353; //Field fj.lc:I 608: aload_2 609: iload 17 611: aload_1 612: getfield #366; //Field ij.C:I 615: iadd 616: putfield #351; //Field fj.Bc:I 619: aload_2 620: iload 16 622: aload_1 623: getfield #366; //Field ij.C:I 626: iadd 627: putfield #358; //Field fj.xc:I 630: iload 19 632: ifeq 13 635: iload_0 636: bipush 64 638: if_icmpeq 673 641: aconst_null 642: putstatic #347; //Field M:[S 645: return 646: astore_1 647: aload_1 648: new #193; //class java/lang/StringBuffer 651: dup 652: ldc #29; //String eg.F( 654: invokespecial #413; //Method java/lang/StringBuffer."<init>":(Ljava/lang/String;)V 657: iload_0 658: invokevirtual #415; //Method java/lang/StringBuffer.append:(I)Ljava/lang/StringBuffer; 661: bipush 41 663: invokevirtual #414; //Method java/lang/StringBuffer.append:(C)Ljava/lang/StringBuffer; 666: invokevirtual #412; //Method java/lang/StringBuffer.toString:()Ljava/lang/String; 669: invokestatic #424; //Method sp.a:(Ljava/lang/Throwable;Ljava/lang/String;)Lah; 672: athrow 673: return Exception table: from to target type 5 645 646 Class java/lang/RuntimeException[/code] but when trying to decompile with jad, it says: "Couldn't fully decompile method c" "Couldn't fully resolve all exception handlers in method c"
however, if you look at the exception entry in the method, it is a perfectly valid entry; just as javac would generate it. whats even weirder is that if i open this method in jbe, and click "save method" (without effectuating any changes) it bitches about how BIPUSH instructions at 16, 280, and 295 require a byte to be passed (even though they are bytes). anyways, so what i did was i changed those instructions to SIPUSH instructions, saved the method, and it decompiled perfectly
[b]what the fuck?[/b]
ps attached is the class which contains the method (first method = this one)

item.title: What the fuck
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

pplsuqbawlz:

What, the… What? I don’t get it, 8 bits signed can’t be 250? PROOF OR LIES!

JBE == fail. Perhaps you should’ve read my post and you would’ve realized.

Read full topic

item.title: What the fuck
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

ok then, excuse my word choice… “im just curious as to what elements in that method make jad not decompile the method properly”

Read full topic

printing “couldnt fully decompile…” isnt crashing

i dont want an alternative method of making it decompile successfully, im just curious as to what elements in that method make jad crash

Read full topic

item.title: What the fuck
item.dc:creator: @pplsuqbawlz1 pplsuqbawlz_
item.description:
@pplsuqbawlz1 wrote:

frank_:

…dont delete the exception table, delete the entry that corresponds to the tracing

I figured he’d be too dumb to follow that, but the exception table isn’t even necessary here.

Read full topic

item.title: What the fuck
item.dc:creator: @pplsuqbawlz pplsuqbawlz
item.description:
@pplsuqbawlz wrote:

[quote=“BAsh, post:7, topic:312234”][quote author=abraham2119 link=topic=408660.msg3016473#msg3016473 date=1257220693]
“Couldn’t fully decompile method c”
“Couldn’t fully resolve all exception handlers in method c”

however, if you look at the exception entry in the method, it is a perfectly valid entry; just as javac would generate it.
[/quote]
This is normal. JODE / JAD don’t behave nicely with exceptions even when properly formatted and even when they are not relevant to the bit that its trying to parse. Just strip them out. There is no value in them.

whats even weirder is that if i open this method in jbe, and click “save method” (without effectuating any changes) it bitches about how BIPUSH instructions at 16, 280, and 295 require a byte to be passed (even though they are bytes). anyways, so what i did was i changed those instructions to SIPUSH instructions, saved the method, and it decompiled perfectly

JBE can’t handle BIPUSH properly. When it parses the class file it sees “BIPUSH 250” so it prints that. When it tries to parse it however it expects the integer to be in the range -128 to 127. Obviously this is in error. It should accept 0 to 256 or output -128 to 127. Using SIPUSH gets around this limitation even though it wastes the a byte.

I don’t know how loading and saving it in JBE fixes it. Probably an issue with jump offsets or something equally mundane that a byte code library like ASM abstract and dispose of. Use ASM or BCEL and run a verifier over the method.

what the fuck?

Indeed. Why can’t you just ask the question and give it a meaningful topic title?[/quote]

What, the… What? I don’t get it, 8 bits signed can’t be 250? PROOF OR LIES!

Edit: Fucking abraham…

Delete the exception table! No one cares about the addition of the runtime exception; if you dont believe me trace all method invokations and look for a “throws” you probably wont find one… But then again you didn’t paste enough information for me to do a proper trace…

Once you’ve deleted the exception table, delete

646: astore_1 647: aload_1 648: new #193; //class java/lang/StringBuffer 651: dup 652: ldc #29; //String eg.F( 654: invokespecial #413; //Method java/lang/StringBuffer."<init>":(Ljava/lang/String;)V 657: iload_0 658: invokevirtual #415; //Method java/lang/StringBuffer.append:(I)Ljava/lang/StringBuffer; 661: bipush 41 663: invokevirtual #414; //Method java/lang/StringBuffer.append:(C)Ljava/lang/StringBuffer; 666: invokevirtual #412; //Method java/lang/StringBuffer.toString:()Ljava/lang/String; 669: invokestatic #424; //Method sp.a:(Ljava/lang/Throwable;Ljava/lang/String;)Lah; 672: athrow 673: return

Recalculate max’s and any other misc information you might want (frames, stackmaps blah blah). And you’re golden, it should decompile…

Read full topic

item.title: What the fuck
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

but why does it not decompile properly?

Read full topic

item.title: What the fuck
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

jbe sucks; it can’t handle negative integers, the text emitted and text expected for parsing invokeinterface are completely different.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: November 03, 2009, 01:25:06 pm[/size][hr]ps abraham this is called tracing

Read full topic

item.title: What the fuck
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

[quote=“abraham2119, post:1, topic:312234”]“Couldn’t fully decompile method c”
“Couldn’t fully resolve all exception handlers in method c”

however, if you look at the exception entry in the method, it is a perfectly valid entry; just as javac would generate it.[/quote]
This is normal. JODE / JAD don’t behave nicely with exceptions even when properly formatted and even when they are not relevant to the bit that its trying to parse. Just strip them out. There is no value in them.

abraham2119:

whats even weirder is that if i open this method in jbe, and click “save method” (without effectuating any changes) it bitches about how BIPUSH instructions at 16, 280, and 295 require a byte to be passed (even though they are bytes). anyways, so what i did was i changed those instructions to SIPUSH instructions, saved the method, and it decompiled perfectly

JBE can’t handle BIPUSH properly. When it parses the class file it sees “BIPUSH 250” so it prints that. When it tries to parse it however it expects the integer to be in the range -128 to 127. Obviously this is in error. It should accept 0 to 256 or output -128 to 127. Using SIPUSH gets around this limitation even though it wastes the a byte.

I don’t know how loading and saving it in JBE fixes it. Probably an issue with jump offsets or something equally mundane that a byte code library like ASM abstract and dispose of. Use ASM or BCEL and run a verifier over the method.

abraham2119:

what the fuck?

Indeed. Why can’t you just ask the question and give it a meaningful topic title?

Read full topic

but when trying to decompile with jad, it says:
“Couldn’t fully decompile method c”
“Couldn’t fully resolve all exception handlers in method c”

however, if you look at the exception entry in the method, it is a perfectly valid entry; just as javac would generate it. whats even weirder is that if i open this method in jbe, and click “save method” (without effectuating any changes) it bitches about how BIPUSH instructions at 16, 280, and 295 require a byte to be passed (even though they are bytes). anyways, so what i did was i changed those instructions to SIPUSH instructions, saved the method, and it decompiled perfectly

what the fuck?
